questions.question: The Data Link Layer involves error detection and correction as part of its core functionality.
Sliding Window Protocols are a fundamental component of the Data Link Layer discussion.
The Data Link Layer focuses on achieving reliable communication between two adjacent machines.
The Data Link Layer provides a well-defined service interface to the Network Layer.
The Data Link Layer is responsible for dealing with transmission errors occurring on the physical link.
Regulating the flow of data so that slow receivers are not overwhelmed by fast senders is a key function of the Data Link Layer.
Framing is a critical design issue addressed by the Data Link Layer.
Error control is a possible service provided by the Data Link Layer.
The Data Link Layer accepts packets from the Network Layer and encapsulates them into frames.
Each standard frame typically contains a frame header, a payload field, and a frame trailer.
The reception of frames involves the process of decapsulation, which is the reverse of encapsulation.
The payload field of a frame specifically holds the packet received from the Network Layer.
The Data Link Layer facilitates data transfer between Network Layer processes on source and destination machines.
Unacknowledged connectionless service is a possible service model within the Data Link Layer.
In unacknowledged connectionless service, a frame is sent without establishing a connection or performing error recovery.
Unacknowledged connectionless service is appropriate when the physical link error rate is very low.
Unacknowledged connectionless service is suitable for real-time traffic like voice where low latency is preferred over perfect reliability.
In networking, late data are often considered worse than bad data for real-time applications.
Ethernet is a common example of unacknowledged connectionless service at the link layer.
In acknowledged connectionless service, each frame sent is individually acknowledged by the receiver.
Acknowledged connectionless service is highly useful over unreliable channels, such as wireless systems.
IEEE 802.11 is an example of a protocol that utilizes acknowledged connectionless service.
In acknowledged connection-oriented service, source and destination machines must establish a connection before data transfer.
Each frame sent over an established connection in the link layer is typically numbered to ensure order.
Acknowledged connection-oriented service ensures that each frame is received exactly once and in the correct order.
In connectionless service, a lost acknowledgment can lead to the same packet being received multiple times.
The Data Link Layer is responsible for breaking the continuous bit stream from the physical layer into discrete frames.
The checksum for each frame is computed and checked at the Data Link Layer, not the Application Layer.
Character count framing uses a field in the header to specify the total number of characters in a frame.
A major disadvantage of character count framing is that errors in the count field make resynchronization very difficult.
Byte stuffing utilizes special flag bytes to delimit frames and escape bytes to handle occurrences of flags in the data.
Byte stuffing increases frame length but simplifies resynchronization after transmission errors.
A major limitation of traditional byte-stuffing is its dependency on 8-bit characters.
Bit stuffing is a framing method performed at the bit level rather than the byte level.
In bit stuffing, the transmitter inserts a '0' bit after seeing five consecutive '1' bits in the data stream.
High-Level Data Link Control (HDLC) is a bit-oriented protocol, not a byte-oriented one.
Physical layer coding violations, such as non-standard signal levels, can be used as a method for framing.
